subject: Re: [junit] Looking for some "Best Practices"
msgSnippet: ... This will be no exception, then :)  IntelliJ IDEA has two kinds of templates, both of which could be useful for generating test cases. One type is a
messageBody:
On Sunday, November 24, 2002, at 08:14 AM, Bill de h√ìra wrote:
> One of the main reasons I'm loyal to JPad pro is the fact that it
> will let me create as many class templates as needed (I have well
> over a dozen for Java alone), including the boilerplate for test
> cases (if anyone here uses JPad Pro and wants them, let me know).
>
> Other tools don't support this very well and I don't understand why-
> I'm mainly thinking about Eclipse and IntelliJ, but often when I say
> these IDEs don't do something, I get corrected ;).

This will be no exception, then :) IntelliJ IDEA has two kinds of
templates, both of which could be useful for generating test cases. One
type is a template for new files, and the other type is a template that
can be inserted at any time (for example, I type "test" and hit "tab",
and "public void test|() { }" is inserted for me (where "|" is the new
location of the text cursor)).

But I don't use it all the time, and I never use the other type of
templates for test case creation because the test cases are so simple:
create a class, have it extend from TestCase, and insert some testXxx()
methods.


Erik
